Comment:
Hi everyone!

This opening is the Meadow Hay Opening and it comes from Easy19's suggestion that I create a themed MT out of this opening.  I ended up playing against a very strong expert in this MT and I seemed to be doing OK.  But then my opponent conjured up Old Matey out of nowhere.  I could have avoided copping this mate but only at the cost of ruinous loss of material.  So, how did this happen?  Firstly I will begin commentary with black's move on Move 4 because that is where the fixed moves end.  The database has completely run out so each player is on their own.
4. ..... Nxa6 - there are several ways to capture this pawn, either with the b7 pawn or with the knight.  My opponent chooses the knight.
4. ..... Nxa6 - there are several ways to capture this pawn, either with the b7 pawn or with the knight.  My opponent chooses the knight.
4. ..... Nxa6 - there are several ways to capture this pawn, either with the b7 pawn or with the knight.  My opponent chooses the knight.
4. ..... Nxa6 - there are several ways to capture this pawn, either with the b7 pawn or with the knight.  My opponent chooses the knight.
4. ..... Nxa6 - there are several ways to capture this pawn, either with the b7 pawn or with the knight.  My opponent chooses the knight.
4. ..... Nxa6 - there are several ways to capture this pawn, either with the b7 pawn or with the knight.  My opponent chooses the knight.
4. ..... Nxa6 - there are several ways to capture this pawn, either with the b7 pawn or with the knight.  My opponent chooses the knight.
5. .... bxa6 - this B for N trade splits up black's queenside pawns and may facilitate material restoration later on.
5. .... bxa6 - this B for N trade splits up black's queenside pawns and may facilitate material restoration later on.
6. b3 - this move prepares a fianchetto on the queenside and a possible move to c4 to try and break up black's strong pawn centre.
8. d3 - preparing Nd2.
8. d3 - preparing Nd2.
8. d3 - preparing Nd2.
8. d3 - preparing Nd2.
10. 0-0 - with my opponent castled kingside, you wouldn't think I was castling into it, would you?
10. 0-0 - with my opponent castled kingside, you wouldn't think I was castling into it, would you?
10. 0-0 - with my opponent castled kingside, you wouldn't think I was castling into it, would you?
10. 0-0 - with my opponent castled kingside, you wouldn't think I was castling into it, would you?
11. Nd2 - my development is nearly complete but black has a big spatial edge.  What an impressive wall of black pawns on the 5th rank!
11. Nd2 - my development is nearly complete but black has a big spatial edge.  What an impressive wall of black pawns on the 5th rank!
13. ..... Qf7 - this is the start of black's dastardly plan.
13. ..... Qf7 - this is the start of black's dastardly plan.
13. ..... Qf7 - this is the start of black's dastardly plan.
13. ..... Qf7 - this is the start of black's dastardly plan.
13. ..... Qf7 - this is the start of black's dastardly plan.
15. Kh1 - Henry sidesteps a possible pin, but this is where he will be boxed in!
15. Kh1 - Henry sidesteps a possible pin, but this is where he will be boxed in!
15. Kh1 - Henry sidesteps a possible pin, but this is where he will be boxed in!
16. Rg1 - it seemed such a good idea at the time - line up rook on same file as enemy queen.  Black showed me that this is not always the case!
16. Rg1 - it seemed such a good idea at the time - line up rook on same file as enemy queen.  Black showed me that this is not always the case!
17. Nf1 - this knight comes down and protects Henry against mate threats on the h column.  It also protects my vulnerable e3 pawn which is now defended by our poor put upon Glenda!
17. Nf1 - this knight comes down and protects Henry against mate threats on the h column.  It also protects my vulnerable e3 pawn which is now defended by our poor put upon Glenda!
18. f4 - an attempt to block off the line of attack of black's dsb.
18. f4 - an attempt to block off the line of attack of black's dsb.
18. ..... Ng4 - allo, allo, allo, suddenly Henry is now in Old Matey's shadow!  Only his dearly beloved better half can defend him now, so Glenda moves to e1 on the next turn.
20. Bc1 - to bolster e3.  Now comes a plethora of exchanges that turn out to be an unmitigated disaster for Yours Truly.
20. Bc1 - to bolster e3.  Now comes a plethora of exchanges that turn out to be an unmitigated disaster for Yours Truly.
20. Bc1 - to bolster e3.  Now comes a plethora of exchanges that turn out to be an unmitigated disaster for Yours Truly.
23. Qg3?? - I think this was my fatal mistake.  I think Bd2 had to be played here.  Do you the Inquest Jury agree?
23. Qg3?? - I think this was my fatal mistake.  I think Bd2 had to be played here.  Do you the Inquest Jury agree?
23. Qg3?? - I think this was my fatal mistake.  I think Bd2 had to be played here.  Do you the Inquest Jury agree?

23. Qg3?? - I think this was my fatal mistake.  I think Bd2 had to be played here.  Do you the Inquest Jury agree?
23. ..... Rxe3!! a brilliant exchange sac!
23. ..... Rxe3!! a brilliant exchange sac!

24. .... Qxh2+!!! - followed by a brilliant queen sacrifice.  Mate cannot be avoided.  Next move I am 9 points up in material but down a king! Sigh and double Sigh!  Not the usual Philidor's Legacy!  Never mind, I did have the consolation over the weekend by managing to add to my tally of Expert Draws with my secret weapon, Operation Joblock.  I will be annotating this game this week so watch this space!
